pros: Benefits are not too bad and the performance bonus can go as high as three months. There are also plenty of guidance, if you are working with the right manager who is willing to guide you. Those in the upper management are rather amiable people.
cons:
While the effort you put in plays a part in determining what you get, which in turn affects your performance bonus, the main determining factor lies in how well you get along with the management and how much they like you.

The company also does not reevaluate ineffective people, and these people can remain in mid-level managerial positions or even get promoted higher up in the hierarchy, placing them in a position where they abuse their power and put down those who are in a lower rank than them. 

Morale can get very low because of the poor management and lack of direction. You are also expected to work weekends and late nights, and there will be demands for you to do so, even if you have prior plans. Even though on the surface, the company promotes the policy of 'work-life balance'. But in truth, there is basically no such thing.

Overall, there are few good managers who would protect their subordinates and treat them fairly. But majority of them only know how to demand and they have no respect for people in a lower rank.

review_title: Good people but too many red tapes
pros:
Good co-workers and you can even make some friends in here

Projects with varying level of challenges

Many new technologies

Good for fresh grads to start in, but not progress in.
cons:
Management is filled with people who like to say "this is how it has been done since time immemorial". So don't ever question them, ever. That is why you can introduce many new technologies but no one can ever use it because of the inertia from the managers.

Most of the time are wasted on red tapes on customer side. Some items can take half a year to clear because of these red tapes.

Some of your co-workers can be quite clueless in their jobs.

Some team leads (with fancy senior titles) are also just as clueless beyond writing a few SQL statements and getting on PM's good side to care about your technical challenges. All they do is ask you is to do it before the deadline.

Slow progression (both in career and salary).

Poor work life balance. You can be expected to stay until midnight and beyond (and come on time on the next day). If not you are expected to answer messages at 11 pm at home. Sometimes you are expected to use your weekends just to meet unrealistic deadlines.

review_title: Depends on who your manager is
job_title: Assistant Customer Service Manager in Singapore
pros: The pay is decent. The work hours are ok. The colleagues are nice and we are like a family of sorts.
cons:
Bureaucracy and there is a 360 employee survey. Some years ago a lot of us in our department working in a massive government project were unhappy with our boss and we highlighted it in the survey.

However, our boss got wind of it and he lectured us for about 1 year, every single meeting for about 1/2 hour that we had better do better in the next employee survey to make him look good. He then also sat down with us one on one and then used vague threats like threatening to close the department down and make all of us in the team lose our jobs. We had bad results for the survey for 2 years and I hope that tells the senior management something. A lot of us left because of this particular manager and many dare not blow the whistle on him because he is vindictive, petty and narcissistic and would give us bad referrals for our future jobs. 

What a joke, seriously, NCS.

job_title: Manager, Business Development in Ang Mo Kio New Town,
pros: Flexi-benefit, 18 days leave. There's lots of activities for bonding with fellow colleagues e.g. Amazing NCS.
cons:
Middle management playing too much politics to make themselves look good to their bosses. First in claiming credit but refuse to help out when you face problems. They will ask you for your solution to the problems you bring to them. You'll be badly rated if your solution didn't manage to resolve the problem and make them look bad on their bosses. 

No job guidance at all. Harsh environment. You'll be expected to bang and fall until you know how to get things done around. Expect a lot of judgements and false accusations.

Poor Worklife balance. There's multiple ocassions we were called back to work on Sat / Sun and the boss didn't respect our timing, being late in the meeting by half an hour on that weekend.

Don't apply for Sales job. They expect you to work till morning to complete your tender and treat it as a mandatory requirement. Top management will only order you around and make you do a lot more jobs but refuse to lift a finger to help. If they did, they'll consider you incompetent for your role.

Don't expect colleagues to be good. Everyone is backstabbing each other trying to look good in front of their bosses.

review_title: Programmers not treated with dignity in this company
pros: Don't have to travel to town for those staying in the north. (For me it's just 2 MRT stations down to Yio Chu Kang). Good exercise every morning because you have to walk at least 500m to the office. No direct bus from YCK MRT station. If you have free time (rarely), you can go to nearby NYP canteen for cheap food.
cons:
Salary is OBSCENELY low. I worked here for 2 years and ZERO pay raise / bonus because i am just a PROGRAMMER in the eyes of my bosses and supervisors despite the fact that I am a local university graduate. Meanwhile the girls doing "business analysis" with ZERO programming knowledge get to earn a higher salary than me. Where is the gender equality they say? 

Wanted to tell you how bad it is but Glassdoor guidelines states " do not post Aggressive or discriminatory language, Profanities, Trade secrets/confidential information" so all I will say is enter at your own risk.

During the 2 years there, I spend most of my weekends finding better paying jobs instead of focusing on adding value to the company because why bother when the company doesn't value your talent.

review_title: A place for fresh graduates to learn.
pros:
NCS is a very good place for fresh graduates or people who are looking to transit to the IT field to learn . 

Reason being is that there are a lot of government projects for you to shuffle to where you can possibly be involved from the start of the development project all the way to production support.
cons:
With the above being said, It is all about your aptitude and your luck. 

You may get to somewhere where you are required to work overtime everyday just to hit the deadline because of unrealistic projections or because the previous crew have all abandoned the project by resigning.  Or if you are lucky a place that is just right for you. 

While there are processes in place, there is no strong organizational culture or leadership.  It is a company made up of hundreds of different teams. 

Remuneration package is fair. But as you grow in this field, don't expect the remuneration package to catch up.

pros: NCS provides good ground for individuals to grow their career; giving the many opportunities to learn and venture into other possible fields within one's field of career. The company is an ideal place for aspiring analysts and technology enthusiasts, for trainings, funded certifications are regularly offered. Employees are well compensated for their efforts and hard work.
cons: Depending on project, one could experience high workload. High turnover rate. Management are less engaging and appears very disinterested with ground work. Managemanent relies greatly on subordinates to deliver the services and often felt disoriented in meetings as they have minimal supervision on the ongoing activities. Appointments are cheaply assigned to lower pay grades without properly evaluating an individual's competency; appears more as a desperation to offload managerial duties.

pros:
Very experienced employees
Competitive pay but not fantastic
Work-life balance is valued and is respected
Result oriented and fair performance ratings. Performance bonuses factor in how you perform against others, and how your department performs against others.
Work-life balance is dependent on the project/department, but is generally valued across the board. However, sometimes projects catch fire and OT is needed. But it's the same for all companies I guess.
A lot of room for learning and growth. Too many projects, too many initiatives, too much interesting work, but not enough people to do.
Many internal initiatives are run to improve the company's processes. 
Very cooperative environment where different teams and departments work collaboratively.
Great Singtel staff benefits!
cons:
Due to the sheer complexity and size of our projects that we win, work often gets extremely stressful. Not for the weak.
Top management is more concerned about numbers than staff.

review_title: Friendly place to work, but performance is based on popularity, not effort
pros:
- Very friendly culture, very nice colleagues
- Tries to promote work-life balance
cons:
- Underperformers are not fired. Instead, they're given a basic performance appraisal and can stay there till they retire.
- Remuneration doesn't match the workload.
- Performance is not based on your outputs but rather, how much your boss likes you and how much you suck up to your boss.
- Stupid culture where staying back late or 'wayanging' is more important than output. You are seen as hardworking if you stay back most nights, even if you are just staring at the screen / surfing Facebook.

review_title: Worst company I’ve been worked for
pros:
This is a place teach you what is working hard but no reward at all.
Canteen is cheap but taste bad.
cons:
1. Rigid management style. Senior managers and above will try all their best to not let you go such as telling you they could see your resume through agents so better not play tricks with them or there is no heaven working place blabla. Senior staff could push most of their responsibilities and tasks to you and they are the ones who take honor.
2. Long working hours. OT in weekend midnight, they allow you to take half day shift. Senior staff are not willing to support at midnight so it’s always me to provide support from 12am to 8am.
3. Very depressed company culture. Everyone in my team is complaining all day and not happy. Clients can be tough and scold you
4. Low pay and poor benefits 
5. New hires are not professional at all. I seriously doubt ncs recruiters will hire anyone who claims to have programming experience. Career managers pretend to care about your career development however not helping at all.
6. Location is not convenient and there is no good restaurant nearby. 
After writing these comments I only regret I should resign earlier.

pros: Plenty of time to rethink what's are best for your site customers. Processes, procedures, new hardware and plenty of new technologies to play around. If you have the clearance, plenty of playground.
cons: Depends which site you are posted to. The site that I am posted. The site manager is a sly, cunning fox and in the business of flipping Prata meaning confirming one thing and changing another, excel at denying staff feedback, insulting staffs intelligence, suppressing his favourite staffs negative feedback. ATSM is appointed by him, being a puppet and excel only in giving what customer wants without thinking of NCS operational needs. WORSE planner for 10 man operations, even lousy for trips to overseas. Loved to ask women workers to give him a shoulder massage. Low EQ, stupidity rides in his management skills, only wants to work to get his monthly paycheck. Loves to walked around in slippers and attend meetings. Overall a selfish manager. No work recognition, taiji culture

review_title: Used to be a good place to work and people oriented... but now it is only concerned about cutting cost!
job_title: Lead Consultant in Ang Mo Kio New Town,
pros: Peers are great, especially if you have been working on the same project for months.
cons: Immediate supervisor is not concern about staff's career roadmap. Poor at retaining staff, many experienced staff quit. Too submissive to customer's request, even for deals that are obviously NOT earning much. The longer you stay there, the harder it is to get promoted to the next level... management rather hire new staff at higher cost and have second thought about upgrading skills of existing experienced staff. Staff attending technical courses - 5 day course squeeze into 3 days. No proper on-the-job training, ... just throw you into the sea and you just learn to swim on your own, that's how you learn!

pros: not much to mention here if you are a person who wants to be groomed or become a leader
cons:
1) It is an inverse pyramid hierarchy structure. you have more managers than engineers. And this is a company shifting from being an SI to Product developer.
2) Careless leaders exist who dont care about the consequence of major mistakes in project execution
3) Most of the people are still with the SI mentality. If you are technology person, you would understand nearsightedness of these people.
4) Forget about work-life balance.
5) Work-skill mismatch is a common sight. The level of politics is like playing 'N' Dimensional chess. You will lose for sure
6) Lack of vision for what they are trying to do. Aggravated by frequently changing top management people (within months).
NOTE: Very rarely some teams are not like this. But you know, you need to work with other teams too. You will get the picture.

pros: Lots of opportunities to pickup technical & soft skills, as their local customers are mostly government, so you learn how to manage difficult people. How also pickup various technical skills as you will be involved in various projects with various requirements.
cons: HR policies too inflexible and slow to act. There is a lack of cooperation between teams & departments. Interdepartmental cooperation depends more on budget and ensuring that the projects are completed successfully. More emphasis placed on soft skill training rather than technical skills. Senior management do not seem to have a clear picture of the things happening in the battlefront.

job_title: Lead Consultant, IT Security in Singapore
pros: Gained working experiences from government Cloud projects.
cons: Working location in Singapore is not suitable for me anymore. I am away from my family.

review_title: NCS used to be a good place to work, but a lot has changed.
pros: A perfect place for mediocre performer. You can stay on the job forever even if you produce poor quality work. A good place to work if you can work with many incompetent people.
cons: The company has lost many highly competent people over the past 10 years. As a result, the identity, culture, good practices....People were nice and you know the names from other depts, not much politics, everyone is committed to common cause, willing to work hard and solve problems together..... all these were lost and not replaced. The new culture is one that is trying to save your own neck, struggling to cope with never ending work, trying hard just to stay afloat....

review_title: Decent benefits with top down management culture
pros:
- Good exposure to both infrastructure and software development side of IT
- Benefits are pretty decent
- Appraisal system is detailed and tracking by KPI allows proper assessment of how well an employee is doing
cons:
- Company has fair bit family friendly programs, but reality on the ground is that with the working hours and the workload (especially in software development projects), employees do not actually get to participate in them. 
- Company has gone through several reorganisations in recent years, and management systems keeps on evolving without the previous system getting a chance to work out all its issues.
- Highly top-down management style, which may not suit employees who dislike being micromanaged

pros:
Staff benefit will be better than normal as what's governed by a normal standard benefits. Big company where your work is very specific and most probably do not have to work Overtime and you are clear what's your work. 
Alot of OTs if you falls under a department with alot of tenders.
cons:
Might be pressed to show face by participating in events/charities and handle activites. HR is not standing on the employees side, they are always on the higher management 's side. You can either risk being a high flyer and prosper or leave;  or live a boring life at the lower level. Even the employee survey usually is for show (which is common in many organisations). 
Not much help among the colleagues with regards to work. However, they are always willing to talk on non-work topics. And your fate depends on your boss and department.

pros:
1. Great manager (at least from my team)
2. Well organized when distributing tasks
3. Most of the colleagues are nice
cons:
1. Obviously some politics here
2. Skillset does not grant you a challenging task to deal with (They say they want challenger spirit but the real case is not, so you will learn slow or you have to self-learning by yourself)
3. When tasks go tense then long-hour and heavily stressed. It felt quite weird that, as a developer, you will sometimes receive some tasks need to be finished in a ridiculously short time span and then later get a ridiculously long time span to do some just average simple stuff. It feels bad to do long-hour but it feels heavily painful when there is nothing to do, to be honest

pros: Good for lower level consultants, but don't stay more than 2 years. There's nothing for you to learn after that.
cons:
Absolutely zero leadership from the very top, i.e. CEO - GM level. Most of the folks are not qualified to lead, had been there since Day 1, or hired on whims and fancy. Wrong people remains, good people left in a hurry. Check out with your friends and headhunters who were the folks who left recently within last 6 months and figure out for yourself. 

Absolutely zero work-life balance. You work 15 hours/day and even on weekends, all because of bad management - shifting of goalposts, directionless, whims and fancy, shoot in the dark.

pros:
- Always make excuses and force employees to catch-up working during weekends and public holidays, even when there is no urgency for it. Good for people who has no family and life. You will not be alone outside your working hour.
- Purposely schedule meetings after office hour, which can last until almost midnight. Good for person who does not need to go home.
- A lot of overtime without compensation. Good for encouraging employee to contribute to the progress of the company.
- Time logging system which supervisor does not allow employee to clock the real working hours, instead logging the working hour which management want to see. Good practice for people who only want to see good things.
- Lower pay compare to market. Good to attracting real talent who think that money is not everything.
cons:
- Atrocious claim system to discourage employees to submit their claims by mandating a lot of offline approval process.
- No thirteenth month bonus
- Imbalance performance appraisal system, where employees are rewarded more for doing nothing rather than those serving and doing the dirty work facing the customers.

pros: Colleague are nice, direct boss very good to his/her team member
cons: Hard to convert to perm, they prefer to hire new staff instead of convert loyal and talented existing stuff, and project are alway with OT and pain, need to sacrifice personal time to work.

pros: Good for fresh graduates. Fresh graduates eventually have a higher base salary and they are taken care by the training department called NuCleuS for the first two years.
cons: In general, poor upper management and not good in the long run. Fresh graduates will have a higher base salary compared to seniors as the management did not put in enough effort to make salary adjustments. It's also hard for you to move across department, once you're stuck in that department you will be stuck forever as the management did not put effort to find someone replace you. Most of their maintenance projects are using old technology as well, so if you're not keen on those NCS is not an option for you.

review_title: Good company to join if you want to find out different aspect of IT industry
pros:
Good opportunity to learn different aspect of IT industry.  Friendly colleagues and reporting officer at least fo rmy case.

You will have plenty of opportunity to be deployed to different projects after you completed one, or request to be transferred.  Good training programs are also avaiable which really enhances both your soft and hard skills.

Work environment is also very nice, comfortable and spacious cubicles with some what less strict work hours, meaning as long as you can finish your task, they won't really bother when you come into office.
cons: Career growth seems rather limited unless you stay for a long time.  Customer from parent company is very demanding, althought there are good ones around.

pros:
Ample of opportunities to learn for fresh graduates
Great working environment and co-workers who can be called friends
Work-life balance can be achieved (OT is occasionally required during project peak periods)
Competitive salary
Good corporate benefits (annual leave, study leave, Singtel mobile plan discount, etc)
Interesting projects that are large and complex
Senior Leadership at NCS is serious about its internal transformation and places it as a high priority
cons:
Career growth is highly dependent on the project you are assigned to
Clients in Singapore tend to squeeze vendors dry (but that's to be expected)

review_title: Safe but boring place to work
pros:
1. Friendly colleagues
2. You will probably never get fired unless you somehow screw it up so badly
3. Good learning ground at a slow pace
4. Good work life balance
cons:
1. Colleagues can be very unmotivated and incompetent
2. Middle management tend to be chaotic and plan poorly
3. Hiring process can be improved
4. Colleagues tend to be late for meeting / work 
5. Long turnaround time for emails / tasks done

review_title: Work work and more work with low base salary
pros: good environment. immediate management is easy on you. little office politics involved. if you work off site, colleagues and superiors are pretty chill with you official working timings.
cons:
if you have work, you work overtime like there's no tomorrow. this is because your superior also tends to promise too much to the clients.

The base salary is too low. if you work off site, there are no cubicles to work in. the HR department is too systematic and is inflexible to changing their renumeration and benefits to what you want.

review_title: Failed Integrity and Lack of Employee Support
pros: The users or employees we were supporting were understanding and patient... oh wait - they are NOT NCS employees but from Changi Hospital
cons: The managers are manipulating the service level beyond integrity level just "for show" that the management are doing a great job for the CIO to see. The truth is they are forcing the helpdesks and field engineers to falsify the records. When users complain about the slow resolution, the Managers and newly hired Managers blames the helpdesks and field engineers and kick them out of the company while some were forced to resign. This has been going on for a year and we don't have time to file a formal complaint against them, who would want to risk their name right?!

pros: Nothing. This is a company that should go die long time ago if not for government contract. Benefits are not even good on paper. Seriously... do a serious thinking if you find this company is attractive.
cons:
Salary is not competitive.
Your boss only know about need to hit KPI.
Keep on telling you company need to cut cost.
Totally no work-life balance.
1 people need to handle  2 to 3 people job scope.
Poor benefits.
Help is never found in the middle and upper management, instead, you will find a lot of fingers pointing at you for not meeting timeline.

review_title: Good for Fresh Grads, Bad for Long Term
pros:
1) Competitive pay for fresh grads, even those from universities not well recognised
2) Structured training programme for entry-level fresh hires
3) Friendly staff
cons:
1) Lack of salary progression despite company growth
2) Tedious, over-structured and ineffective performance review process
3) Poor utilisation of manpower; some are very busy and overburdened, others can go for coffee breaks all day
4) Complete lack of transparency in renumeration policies

pros: Low increase, sometimes high bonus but does not apply to all.
cons: High demand of your time. Consultants need to work long hours. Sometimes 34 hours during delivery period.

job_title: Applications Consultant in Bukit Merah Estate,
pros:
System integrator means challenges and overtime. Colleagues are generally nice while project managers are depending on individual. Exposure to entire development (deployment, coding, various phases of sdlc). 
There are things like performance metrics and KPI for the company to track you and you to track yourself. Career managers are available to help you like switching projects and track your progress, however it is really up to individual.
cons:
Hours can be really dependent on project.
No 13th month, bonus is tied to performance which is unfortunately tied to the project you are in.

pros: Good colleagues.  Great environment to learn. Have a great boss who will protect his staff. Singtel/NCS dish out some great benefits for staff welfare. HR is doing a great job, but only if they know how the directors/project managers/service delivery managers squeeze the engineers/consultants just to meet expectations.
cons:
1) Low salary.
2) Different teams working on a project do not work well with each other.
3) Directors handling an operation project will throw anyone under the bus. Will tell you to do everything under the sun even if not within job scope. Do not know how to manage clients expectations.

pros: Company is going through transformation now and it's a good time to be here if you want to make significant changes.  There are lot's of new initiative to improve work processes and  more transparency in what the management is planning ahead.  The new CEO is a very sincere and people-centric person, he is serious in making a change in NCS, to make it a better place for the staff and improve our business in the region.
cons: With massive transformation, comes lot's of work to make it happen. OT is common in some departments but it's made better now that staff can work from home..

pros: Good local presence and strong government link engagements and projects.  Good risk management to help mitigate huge risk to the company.
cons: Too much red tapes and effort spent on qualifications, and yet there are many gaps and things not running smooth as it should be.  Business strategy may be there, but not properly flow down to working level, staff "just do it" for the sake of meeting KPI on paper only, and waiting for direction to change course and do the same "just do it" attitude all over again.

pros: Good local presence and strong government link engagements and projects.  Good risk management to help mitigate huge risk to the company.
cons: Too much red tapes and effort spent on qualifications, and yet there are many gaps and things not running smooth as it should be.  Business strategy may be there, but not properly flow down to working level, staff "just do it" for the sake of meeting KPI on paper only, and waiting for direction to change course and do the same "just do it" attitude all over again.

pros: Employee benefits are good; medical, flexi-benefits etc, for work and superiors-wise, it depends on project.  But overall, company is structured and inclusive.
cons: Promotion is hard to get and it also depends on your project. When project requires resources or advice, it's not clear where or how to get and so things are to get moving.

job_title: Senior Software Architect in Ang Mo Kio New Town,
pros: Good Medical Package, On time payment of Salaries.
cons: Top Management is politically divided among groups and departments, which hinders the overall performance of the company goals. Resource allocation is thoroughly questionable, a manager might choose his favourite "henchmen" in his race, rather than a resource with matching skills and talent. Lot of skilled people leave the company due to this.

pros: Big Company, good learning ground for fresh grad, good salaries for fresh grad.
cons:
Higher management doesn't care about your opinion, they only interest about their KPI.
Benefit cut down a lot after Singtel took over the HR. E.g. Remove AWS. Bonus reduce.
New promotion structure make us "nearly" impossible to get promote. Especially those fighting in the front line. 
Your work life balance and bonus depends on the project/department you join.

pros:
- Competitive pay
- Generous benefits
- Variable Bonuses
- Learn from experienced colleagues
cons:
- If you are unlucky, your performance will be reviewed by a reporting officer who does not know you as he/she is based elsewhere. They make no effort to contact you or your Team Leader, who is able to give honest feedback. Happened to a former colleague as his identity was mistaken for another under-performing staff

- Too many middle-managers

- Company treats on-site support staff (based in clients' locations) like robots; giving last minute news that they will be moved to another location

- Career progression is slow

pros:
Staff discount for Singtel services.
Good exposure to emerging technology in IT sector.
Company will ensure that you are well equipped to perform your job.
cons:
Pervasive bottomline driven culture.
Lack of unity within the organization.
Some teams are over stretched and unable to deliver in accordance to what was committed. 
Backend units reluctant to support small value projects.
Senior management is not in sync with ground workers.

pros:
Friendly People

That is all I can think of.
cons:
- Management doesn't protect the staff from demanding clients.
- Management are Yes man towards clients.
- Higher Management such as directors always avoid meeting the clients.
- Performance rating system sucks. Even if everyone in your team perform well there must be a rate 5 in the team.
- Ever since Singtel takes over the bonus is getting worse every year.
- No career advancement.
- After working for 7 years and been getting good performance ratings but no promotions.
- Good performance = who OT the most and not to those who are the most efficient.
- Managers does play favorites

review_title: A sugar-coated local company that package like a MNC.
pros:
-Work-life balance
-Good boss
-Good and affordable food 
-Lots of events for staff
-Salary package is attractive
cons:
-Environment is just terrible and filthy. Badly need a renovation.
-Time to upgrade the equipments. They are still using a dial button phone which is so old it can be consider as antique. 
-Due to having a lot of old timers, they are not helpful when you need advise or help. The most common reply they use will be "Sorry can't help" or "That's not my responsibility"
-Avoiding work/responsibility is common.
-No standard procedure.

pros: good bonding between fellow junior developers/consultants
cons:
1. Senior consultant lacks of technical skills and knowledge (totally incompetent). Please imagine that they cant even do a proper SQL query.

2. Overload the juniors with work scopes that belongs to the seniors. 

3. Incompetent manager, can talk cannot do; only act as a relay between consultants  and end users. Cant do proper resource management and task allocation.

4. Lack of real developers, which caused tight schedules and also due to management overpromising to the clients. Eventually, a lot of the change requests skipped SIT or even UAT; ending up delivering products of low standard and quality.

5. Slow progression or no progression at all, imagine your project's head count got more seniors than juniors. 

6. The bonus is not appealing.

pros:
Little politics at the lower levels.
Lower level staff are generally helpful.
They should be appreciated more.
cons:
You arrive, slightly earlier than business operating hours, and announce to the receptionist that this is your first day of work. You smile at her. 

She smiles back. "Please key in your details into this touchscreen," she says. "I will contact your assigned HR who will generate your temporary pass and bring you in past the gantry."

You wait, eager to start work and do a good job for your new company. 

You wait some more, feet getting tired. It's been half an hour and the only seats in sight are taunting you behind the gantry.

You wait. Impatient and stony-faced. It's been an hour. You hope  that this experience is not representative of the rest of your time with this company.

You are so, so wrong.

pros: It is a good place for lower level technical staff. Good project managers. Make sure you stay technically involved in the projects and avoid being "promoted" up the chain. Stay at Technical Lead level will be ideal. Otherwise you will be stuck with clueless business/account leaders, ineffective resource management and tonnes of reporting while management avoid the real issues.
cons: Very bad top management, resulting in high turnover of good leaders. Turnover is especially high in new growth areas due to lack of top management vision and support. If you are thinking of coming in as an Assistant Director and above, think twice before accepting any offer. Any level lower than that is probably ok but keep your eyes/ears open. Zero worklife balance. Be prepared to work beyond reasonable effort for extended periods.

review_title: Managers act like assembly line supervisors, employers especially foreigners are exploited and treated like slaves
pros:
Lots of projects.
Will have work for years since the company indirectly owned by government.
Better Bonus for people with some selected skin color.
cons:
Working over time is expected always.
All the tough/difficult/low budget projects will be executed with foreigners and they will will be squeezed and thrown after  use like toilet papers.
Racism.
Managers  behave like assembly line supervisors. They do not know the difference between assembly line job and software development. 
Only people of particular skin types get compensatory off for working on off days.

pros: In-house canteen, lunchtime shuttle to shopping malls and clubhouse (if you have time to use it)
cons: HR seemingly takes care of other people's welfare, but ours are not well taken care of. Management style makes working here mentally draining and affects morale. Efforts seldom recognized but mistakes amplified. High turnover rate in recent years.

pros:
Pretty competitive pay to me. 
Pretty easy entry.
cons:
Pretty poor middle management at PM level. 
Developers are under valued than so called Business Analyst especially those crappy senior-titled with 0 technical background. Most even fail to fulfil their role of requirement engineering and value optimize. Not even clear with the scenario and test data. What they know is, "let developer do it", and guess who got promoted first?

PM just dont make sense. Trying to squeeze work and request weekend work. No OT and timeoff is being compensated ofcourse.

pros: Less political and provide good exposure for fresh grads. There is even a post-grad program for fresh grads nowadays. Experience varies among projects. Some projects have good colleagues, bad managements, vice versa, etc.
cons: Based on my project experience, the management is very unprofessional looking from a software development point of view. Sometimes, I don't know if the project is inside any SDLC. Management just tell you something need to be done and implemented, maybe in a few days time, etc. and you have gotta deliver it. That kind of thing, you get it.

review_title: No Work Life Balance - Boss will tell you "you don't have a choice"
pros: some of the colleagues are nice, only too busy to get better bondings
cons:
65~70% of the company are FTs. 
Assign ONLY 4 ppl to work on the task for 1 big govt project (only locals can work on the job)... 24/7 standby n always got waken up by the boss in the middle of the night to start working, avg sleep 3~4hrs per day... but all these is dependant on the project you got,  JOIN AT OWN RISK

review_title: Generally OK but depends on your immediately supervisor
pros: Experiences vary and are largely due to your direct manager. However, as an organisation, the benefits are decent, there are regular corporate level activities for staff. Applications tower appears to be slightly better run than infrastructure tower...
cons: Mostly technology focused company. There isn't much training or career path for anyone who doesn't deal with technology; e.g. Governance, service management.

pros: If you know to lick the boot of management then you will enjoy your stay.
cons:
1.  I have worked for other MNCs but never found a company of 5k+ employee with virtually no processes, no coding standards (there are few exceptions to this).

2. Most of the managers are worthless. Their appraisal of employee  is greatly influenced by their interaction (read lunch,coffess, buttering) etc with the employee rather than the work the employee does.

3.  Good bonuses are only for Managers. Appraisal is a joke.

4. Company with this size has virtually no training system. Their are few trainings but that too just to promote their outdated platform or for the technologies that are outdated. 

5. Most of the  Programmers working with here for more than 3-4 years hardly are aware of the latest techonologies.

6. Awards are joke.

pros: Good exposure to large public sector customers. These clients often have big budgets and highly visible projects.
cons:
Behaves like a large public sector agency. Slow to react to changing market conditions and unwillingness to invest in staff training on new technologies.

A strong culture of self preservaton, over the good of the company.  Staff who has worked here for a long time are keen to keep outsiders from good opportunities, but instead force them to be scape goats for failing projects.

pros: People are friendly and helpful.
cons:
- Company fail to realise that if they want to contact employees throughout the week, then they should provide / pay for the phone bills! But they dont and they expect you to use your data to do official work.
- very poor privacy in treating your personal mobile number. They dont under the word PERSONAL!!!

pros: Lots of interesting projects, great pay and bonus.  Usually there’s work life balance unless during project peak periods. Loads of online resources to do self learning, courses/workshops,great healthcare benefits, discounts,  generous annual leave, flexi leave.  Good upper management.
cons: Toxic work culture, since most of the employees are of varying cultures and nationalities, they don’t gel together that well.  A lot of politics and there’s no sense of team camaraderie . Everyone stabs everyone else and cover their own backs. The seniors, lead have god complexes, you can frequently hear lead/ seniors saying “I will slap you ah”, “How come you dont know this”, appalling lack of professionalism for such a big company and they expect their opinions to be held with high regard. If they mess up, you won’t hear about it. Everyone overlooks it. You mess up, you will be belittled and sufficiently told off.  The seniors will lick the leads/pms’s boots and you are expected to lick their boots.  I have heard that it is more or less the same in other projects too. There are also a bunch of seniors with over 5 years of experience who only know how to delegate tasks and barely able to write SQL statements, they will push all their tasks to the juniors. Another downside is that there is no OT pay though many work on weekends during peak periods. Salary increment is also very low. They offer good starting pay but the yearly increment is ridiculously low.

review_title: Great as a stepping stone. Great experience. Not advisable to stay too long especially if you are recently graduated.
pros: Lots of exposure due to many big government projects
cons:
Terrible compensation package
No real recognition for good work
Mid management lily gilds everything, makes them look good, makes upper management feel good, employees suffer.
Never hear or see senior management do anything.
Lots of lip service pep talks and perks
Customers first, rank and file employees expendable
Management afraid to say no to customers, employees suffer overtime for it.
Extremely short term minded management.

review_title: Depressing place to work over long term.
job_title: Network Consulting Engineer in Ang Mo Kio New Town,
pros:
-You'll meet some decent people at work.
-Gain basic working experience.
-Decent exposure to IT devices and technology.
-Learning to be independent is natural instinct upon working at NCS.
-Depends on your luck you could land in a very good team with excellent supportive managers and team leads on rare occasions.
cons:
-The very starting low salary will impact your long-term career salary in Singapore. So new engineers are aware.
-Having unfriendly HR experience (it's like conversing with a delinquent at times due to intended misinformation from others.)
-Hard Work and dedication to succeed objectives and helping others, doesn't seem to be appreciated in some places.
-Policial driven environment which negatively impacts morales of the workers.
-Some Managers lack the authoritative leadership.
-Some managers are too compliance to customers non-stop demands as the result engineers suffer.
-Customers are able to dictate engineers leaves and days offs due to the above.
-Customers are allowed to overworked the engineers due to the above.
-No work/life balances due to above.
-Customers are able to drag engineers into unnecessary office politics (a.k.a bully) due to managers not standing in way even after sounding off to the manager.
-Expressing/disclosing your current displeasure matters at work (politely manner of course) to your superiors would get you into trouble instead of resolving it.
-The high turn overrate is no coincidental or accident due to office politics.

pros:
Good starting ground.
Seasonal work load, on a sunny day its almost like a vacation.
Worked with some of the greatest hard working colleagues.
cons:
Not for the weak hearted.
Expect lots of unplanned overtime, weekends and out of scope tasks.
Seasonal work load, when it rain it pours.
Work smart is nowhere to be found.
Low average salary for the amount of stress you will face.

review_title: work often on weekends and public holidays
pros:
variable bonuses, flexible claim benefits and staff phone plan discounts.

good colleagues and bosses depending on which project, customer site and manager skills.

training courses and certification exams provided.
cons: poor work life balance, do expect to spend holidays on work,  projects often not enough resources, one need to have very good time planning and mental endurance to do well in this job.

review_title: Good place to learn but don't stay too long
pros:
Lots of opportunities to learn as long as you are willing to work hard.

For sales, base salary is not high but overachieving is possible.

Flexible working hours for sales unless there is a tender submission to rush for.
cons:
Too many organizational changes past few years.

Very weak Lob support for sales when engaging customers. 

Too much redundant paperwork for sales resulting in 80% of time being internal facing.

Delivery quality has dropped significantly due to lack of resources, in terms of quantity and quality.

review_title: Policies in place but messy in execution
pros: Rather supportive management up till two levels up.
cons:
It is after all a profit driven company, so it will take on projects regardless there is sufficient resources - quality and quantity, as long as it can win the tenders.

There are work processes and policies in place, but the execution, or the lack of, is rather bad.

Inter-business units collaboration can be an issue.

pros:
- Good friends, was hired under nucleus program, most of my batchmates become good friends of mine.
- I have had the most passionate bosses in NCS(sadly they don't last long here)
- stable income, had a few salary raise. Although HR over promise the bonus(lower to whatever mentioned during phone interview despite having good Performance Rating).
cons:
- I have had the worst bosses in NCS as well, just tai-chi stuff and blow smoke(sadly there are a bunch of them here) so be prepared. Most PMs are not technically strong so be well prepared to work with such people and they are the one who will grade your performance rating. most of the times gives outdated advices.
- if you are hired under nucleus program, by right the career manager suppose to "guide" you so that you perform better and can climb easier. Majority are ok, some still need to be improved as they are really do not know what's going on in your project/technology trends. so be your own career manager, testing your CV in the market is the best career advice that you could ever receive. Build your portfolio and aim to resign on late July is best :)
- NCS is undergoing restructuring, which is good, seems like they are trying to up-skill their staffs to bring new business to NCS. But ever since the announcement was made in Aug 2019, I have NEVER had the opportunity to attend any course. So don't hope so much on career growth here. 
- some will still speak in their own language (other than english) in formal meetings internal and with external customer. I brought this up to HR, of course their answer is, please bring it up to your manager. But what to do if your manager is in the meeting and aware of it but decide to take no action?

review_title: Used to be good; a sad shadow of its former self
pros:
- Lots of work - which means lots of opportunity to pick up skills.
- project teams tend to be tight knit - you make good friends with colleagues that worked together to achieve a common goal.
cons:
- Long hours with no clear compensation for it, either in time-off or it's equivalent
- If you don't stay in a project long enough for your boss to appreciate your efforts, you can kiss your promotions good bye.
- Management used to be good, now replaced by questionable individuals. 
- If you're not in an implementation project, be prepared for God awful increments even though your performance grading is above average.

review_title: Good for experienced, Not recommended for beginners.
pros:
Decent pay and good company benefits( better benefits then average ).
Learn to be dependent.
Opportunity to experience SDLC and Agile Development.
Some colleagues are friendly, depending on the team that you were assigned.
cons:
Timeline driven implementation resulting on poor quality product. Project Manager's constantly rushes development to meet deadline, developers have to work overtime frequently to meet unreasonable project deadlines. No proper quality control over developed products for certain projects, resulting in many issues during post-production phase, increasing the effort needed to maintain the project, as well as impacting the Service Level Availability as agreed. 

"As long as it works and it meet customer requirements, then it is ok" kind of attitude results in poor product quality. Managers does not set KPI resulting in unfair appraisal. Poor language proficiency in main communication language has also impacted development timeline. Imagine a simply question requires few round of email "ping-pong" for clarafication. Not fully utilizing available softwares, such as using outlook to facilitate meeting appointments and meeting room booking, causing much hassle in securing a booking room. Higher level management that is handling a "more" important project may "Kick" lower priority and / or smaller project's out of meeting room whenever meeting venue is not available, illustrating the lack of respect towards other projects and other employees.
Job role is clearly distinguished where Business Analyst refuses to discuss Technical Issues with Programmers, resulting in poor communication and designs that does not fulfill the customer requirements.

pros: No worthy pros to mention, maybe there is a child care center within should you require such services. not much control over time that you report for work. air con is freezing cold (given that weather is so hot now) and the staff canteen is newly renovated
cons: Poor project planning in terms of preparing a team to handle the project; poor team forming in terms of skill sets and experience, lack of leadership within the team, orientation for newly created team is non-existent despite the fact that the team is large and comprises of different sections. poor interpersonal handling from project manager, lack of work-life balance in sense. etc

pros:
Benefits
Trying to make efforts to be professional
cons:
Lack of support from higher management.
Depending what project u r in, it can be a very hostile environment. Will change ur job scope at will. Lot of staffs that stayed long usually cannot make it.

review_title: Good if you like working in a government like institution.
pros: -Very regimental. The processes are all in place. If you are the type of person, who don't like huge changes, this is the place to be.
cons:
-Very low pay as very often, your role can be covered by a FT who can do your job at half your asking salary
-Too Regimental

pros: Job security. Projects keep coming from government organizations.
cons:
NCS is good only for Singaporean Chinese. People from ethnicities other than Singaporean Chinese  will not able allowed to progress nor get to take vacations. Upper management will continuously keep rejecting vacation and work life balance is very low and the rating will be low.

Most of the upper management is not well versed with latest technologies. 

Company doesn't have any global presence and the culture is very Singaporean with lot of Singlish around. Come here to lose all the good English you have. 

One has to be bootlicking the managers and also go with lunch with them all time or else one will be left out.

Very bureaucratic culture.

review_title: Stable company, good colleagues and opportunity to learn

job_title: Lead Consultant, Presales in Ang Mo Kio New Town,
pros:
- Freedom to perform own tasks, just ensure work is completed 
- loads of staff benefits
cons:
- people don’t respect your time, you work at night and midnight
- Managers like to tell the vendors not to poach staff, while vendors politely stay away, be aware that you should stay away from the job market for a while should you feel sick with the company, managers categorically deny this but it is a fact
- new CEO brought along his practices from Accenture, now everyone below management is complaining about the timelogging system, you’ll feel burnt out by the end of the month from chasing not sales numbers but the administrative overhead of timelog
- support on a project or a deal is predicated on timelog, whereas in the past an opportunity could be explored, it makes more sense now not to engage (i.e. email/phone calls/visits) unless the account manager opens the timelog that is your cost, if he doesn’t open timelog for whatever reason you are forced to clock the effort somewhere else marked “Unproductive” - you either escalate the issue or you are marked for release
- this forces us to be mercernary with sales, or on the other extreme, cliques form because the structure forces one to pursue work that is exactly what Accenture is known for
- customer requests may look simple but may be complex, this is what the upper management don’t get, we have at least a few incidents where a senior leadership team member made a “that’s an inefficient use of time” remark which was rather insulting, but is used to justify their refusal to grant timelog.
- Self-development and updates are considered unproductive activities.
- annual performance appraisal is on a bell curve. If your direct or indirect manager condemns you, you are better off elsewhere. You can’t be too good because of the need to have the majority within the curve. There is also the need to keep some on the extremes so that the majority are kept happy. Results are never fair.

review_title: I like the people in NCS
pros: If you are not caring about your future then it's okay to refuse any workload and kick back. If you don't want just sit there and do nothing then you can ask to do more. It's quite flexible. Many people choose this company to retire.
cons: If you are in some project with an urgent deadline, then a lot of OT should be anticipated. Most of the times the messes in projects come from lack of management or bad management, also from engineers lack of responsible .

pros: Depending on the project team, working hours can he flexible and able to claim off day for weekend work or working till late on weekdays.
cons:
Poor remnuneration. Annual increment is pathetic. No 13 months AWS. Performance bonus is below market standard. Management always giving lame excuses as to why they can't give u a higher appraisal rating (such as project not making enough money etc). A grade 4 appraisal rating will only give u a max of 1 month bonus.

HR doesn't know how to retain staff who want to stay by offering them a better package.

May be hard to move from one role to another.

pros:
Got a chance to interact and work with different other IT departments (within NCS) as to complete a project for client. Allow you to better understand the life working in IT industry and its areas of scopes. (i.e. Network team, IT management Team, Hardware Team, application teams, etc)
Colleagues were nice, willing to stand in duty for you if you have night classes.
cons: No career advancement and instructions were not give out clearly to people who are in working level at times. Salary increment is little.

pros: A very forgiving and naturing culture.  It has a very structured culture which means that everything is run in a ordering manner.
cons: Lots of processes and the strict structure can be a limitation  Lack of communication from top manager. Changes need a long time to be implemented due to the massive size of the company.

job_title: Consultant in Ang Mo Kio New Town,
pros: If you are put into a slow moving project, it is good, you can take your own time to do your own stuff, but if you are in a fast paced project, you totally have no time to even rest.
cons:
I'm a fresher graduated from uni and joined the new branch of recruitment named 'Nucleus'. 

They are a group of trainers that help to train new recruit to learn the technology that NCS used, namely the iconnect, but the fact is, there are very little people in the market using the ncs framework. Most of NCS project were maintenance, which means that most of these are actually older technology. So there are no use for the training period. The only good thing about this training period is that they give you pay for the six weeks.

So going into the project, you have no idea what you are about to go through. There are a few people in the group whom they think that they are very atas, following the book not allowing any of the staff to break the rule so that the group (nucleus) is not being defamed by any of us. So we basically don't belong to NCS but that nucleus branch. Even when we faced problem, their main concern is that they don't want to affect their reputation because that would affect their performance hence bonus. But this is in the expense of the company productivity and the staff unhappiness.

cons:
- Bias Performance Review : Mgmt will be nice to you and promise everything if you give 200% to justify that you need to OT but the results of the yearly appraisal is the exact opposite. You can use that hard work in other company to get a much better compensation.

- Bias Mgmt : Some department is mostly filled with people of certain nationality and promotion is given to them unfairly. Mgmt will always give the reason of no opportunity/opening/not ready to push away your promotion and penalize your appraisal.

review_title: Pros and Cons - Great company but people need to increase their calibre
pros:
Work Life Balance
Education Support
Conducive work facilities
cons:
Situated in industrial area, lack of food amenities, need to take company shuttle or eat in company cafetaria or a nearby small foodcourt which has limited options. 

Career progress can be slow, depending on the leadership and project management skillset of the leads, many who want to take the credit for themselves instead of looking at recognising the efforts of team members. Can feel left out.

Personally, the role and level of experience i had applied for and the role i got did not match (felt conned by HR), and this was also evident from the compensation (no 13 mth bonus by default, and performance appraisal was not fair). 

Please ensure that the job description in the role match what is assigned, if not its better to consider seeking better roles during the probation period itself.

pros:
1. Slightly above average for total benefits, don't compare with banks or tech giants like Google or Amazon.
2. Depending on the project manager you'll have great time working in the company
3. If you are a fresh graduate you can join their Nucleus program it helps you be onboarded. It helps you experience IT process, Service management Process and Security
4. There is a progression path on how to be promoted. Annual salary increment for average performance is acceptable 
5. Costly certification and trainings are provided if you request it from the project.
6. The new CEO seems very eager to transform the company to become a better company
cons:
1. Some projects are toxic or mishandled, one would be unlucky to be assigned to it
2. No project rotation, you'll get stuck with the same project for a while
3. Prepare to work on weekend and be on call, or on-site if needed

review_title: Good Benefit, Career advancement slow  for maintenance team
pros: Good employee benefit, free training courses.
cons: Salary low and no market adjustment. Work life balance can be hell or heaven based on the project that you are in and your manager. review_title: It is transforming for the better
pros:
Every company has it pros and cons. Despite bad reviews in the past, the company took in suggestions and improve. It might take time but it is definitely moving towards the positive side. 

NCS has a rich community which we can learn from each other. However please note that not everyone would have the same frequency. 

In terms of remunerations, it is competitive if you work hard and smart and not being political in any situation. In terms of comparison with other tech companies, I think it is not too bad depending how you look at it.
cons:
Although NCS is more of both Maintenance and System Integration company, staff like me are based offsite or customer's premises. 

The feeling of being an 'unwanted child' or 3rd party, makes me wonder if the company has forgotten us. 

Yes granted that sometimes work has to be done after office hours or weekends, it would be great that appropriate resources can be allocated if the company advocates 'community' or working together as one.
